questions.text: An elderly man was brought to the hospital with complaints of rapid heartbeat, increased sweating, and dizziness. His ECG is shown below and his BP is 126/82 mm of Hg. The doctor asked him to lie down and turn his head to the left side. He then applied pressure on the right carotid artery just below the angle on the mandible, which lowered the patient's heart rate. Which among the following is the afferent nerve for the manoeuvre performed by the doctor?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the patient is stable, the doctor has performed a carotid sinus massage to slow the heart rate and to convert to sinus rhythm. This stimulates the baroreceptor reflex, whose afferent nerve is the glossopharyngeal nerve. 

Features suggestive of PSVT are:

  • Narrow complex tachycardia at 150 bpm
  • No visible P waves
  • Pseudo R’ waves in lead aVR due to retrograde atrial activation

Carotid sinus massage:

Procedure- It is performed with the patient supine and the head turned slightly away from the side being stimulated. Before performing massage the doctor should always auscultate to check for the presence of carotid bruit. If bruit is present, it should not be performed. The area of the carotid sinus, at the artery’s bifurcation, is palpated with two fingers at the angle of the jaw until a good pulse is felt. A minimal amount of pressure is applied over the carotid sinus. If there is no effect, a side-to-side or rotating motion of the fingers over the site is performed for up to 5 seconds. ECG should be performed to assess the response.

Mechanism- Pressure over the carotid sinus stimulates the baroreceptors. These signals are transmitted through small Hering’s nerves to the glossopharyngeal nerves and then to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. These signals inhibit the vasoconstrictor center of the medulla and excite the vagal parasympathetic centre. The stimulation of the vagus results in a slowing of impulse generation in the SA node and a slowing of conduction velocity in the AV node.  

Other vagal maneuvers which are used to treat cardiac arrhythmias and conduction abnormalities are,

  • Valsalva manoeuvre- the patient is placed in a supine or semirecumbent position and instructed to exhale forcefully against a closed glottis. The patient should maintain this strain for 10-15 seconds and then start breathing normally. It decreases the heart rate and can be used in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.
  • Diving reflex- A patient holds his breath and then immerses his face in the water at a temperature of 10-20 degrees Celsius. It results in bradycardia and can be used to terminate paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. 

Note- Vagus nerve is an afferent for the impulses from the aortic baroreceptors in the arch of the aorta.

questions.text: The electrocardiogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows broad QRS complexes, rSR' pattern in lead V1, and a curved S wave which is wider than the R wave in lead V6. This points to a diagnosis of right bundle branch block (RBBB).

To make a diagnosis of RBBB, the following three criteria should be met:

  1. QRS duration >120 ms.
  2. rSR' pattern present in leads V1 or V2. The R' is usually wider than the initial R wave.
  3. S wave of greater duration than the R wave in leads V6.

Bundle branch blocks occur due to a block in the conduction in the right or the left bundle system below the AV node. RBBB is often seen in patients with no underlying heart disease, while left bundle branch block (LBBB) is seen associated with ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and valvular heart disease.

Other options:

Option B: The ECG findings suggestive of LBBB include:

  • QRS duration >120 ms
  • Broad, notched, or slurred R wave in leads V5 or V6
  • Absent q waves in leads V5 or V6
  • QS (no preceding R wave) or rS (small R wave but deep S wave) complexes in lead V1

The image below shows QRS patterns in the right and left bundle branch blocks:

 

Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome occurs due to an abnormal conduction pathway in the cardiac tissues between the atria and ventricles. ECG will show the following features:

  • A shortened PR interval 
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex 

The image below shows the delta waves in WPW syndrome

 

Option D: In ventricular bigeminy, every normal QRS complex is followed by a premature ventricular contraction, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency room and was diagnosed with an arrhythmia. The duty doctor tried to manage it by performing a carotid sinus massage. A normal pacemaker potential curve is shown in the image below. Identify the change expected to be seen in this curve after carotid sinus massage.
questions.solution:
The change expected to be seen in this patient after carotid sinus massage is a decrease in the slope of phase 4 of the pacemaker potential curve.

Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver that is used to treat arrhythmias by activating the baroreceptor mechanism. The carotid sinus contains baroreceptors that get activated on physical manipulation. This mechanism, via the nucleus tractus solitarius, sends parasympathetic vagal efferents to the heart.

Phases of pacemaker potential:

  • Phase 0- Upstroke. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3- Downstroke. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-type Ca2+ channel.

In the clinical scenario, due to vagal stimulation, the parasympathetic cholinergic fibers to the SAN are stimulated. This leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by two mechanisms-

  1. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated→ slowed depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ decreased slope. 
  2. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated → decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)→ decreased firing of T-type Ca2+ channel → decreased slope.

On the other hand, the response to sympathetic stimuli is that of an increased slope of the pacemaker potential. This effect is mediated by two mechanisms-

  1. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → β1 receptor → increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) → rapid opening of L-type Ca2+ channels → increased slope. 
  2. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → increases the depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ increased slope. 

The image given below shows the effect of sympathetic and parasympathetic stimuli on the pacemaker potential:

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient came for a routine check-up. An electrocardiogram was done, which is given below. What is the most probable finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
First-degree heart block is the most probable finding in the given electrocardiogram (ECG).

The ECG image shows a prolongation of the PR interval by >0.20 seconds, which is indicative of first-degree heart block.

First-degree heart block is the abnormal slowing of the conduction through the atrioventricular node. It is characterized by a prolonged PR interval >0.20 seconds without disrupting the atrial and ventricular conduction. The normal PR interval is from 0.12 seconds to 0.20 seconds. 

Some of the common causes of first-degree heart blocks are coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, infections, electrolyte abnormalities, drugs, and collagen vascular diseases. Most of the patients are usually asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally. In high-grade first-degree heart block (PR interval >0.30 seconds), patients develop symptoms like dyspnea, chest pain, or syncope.

For the majority of patients with first-degree AV block, there is no need for treatment. In patients with a PR interval greater than 0.30 seconds, who are experiencing symptoms believed to be due to the AV block, pacemaker placement may be required. In patients with AV block related to myocardial infarction (MI), pacemaker placement may be indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Type I Mobitz (Wenckebach) block is a subtype of second-degree heart block. It is characterized by progressive prolongation of the PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause (dropped beat) that is less than 2 times the immediately preceding RR interval. The shortest PR interval occurs after the pause and the longest PR interval occurs before the pause.

The below image shows the type I Mobitz heart block.

Option C- Type II Mobitz block is also a subtype of second-degree heart block. It is characterized by an intermittent failure of P wave conduction without any change in the preceding impulses. There is no progressive prolongation of PR interval like in type I Mobitz block. 

The below image shows the type II Mobitz block.

Option D- Complete heart block/third-degree heart block is the complete failure of conduction from the atrium to the ventricles. It is characterized by no relationship between the P wave and QRS complex, P waves more than QRS complexes, and equal RR and PR intervals. A junctional or ventricular escape rhythm maintains the ventricular conduction.

The below image shows the complete heart block.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and COPD presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG is given below. Given his medical history, what is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism contributing to his ECG findings?

COPD: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

ECG: Electrocardiogram

choices.text: Increased automaticity in the sinoatrial node
Reentry circuits within the atrioventricular node
Ectopic foci originating from the pulmonary veins
Conduction delay due to bundle branch block

questions.solution:
The most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism contributing to atrial fibrillation in this patient, given his history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and COPD, is the presence of ectopic foci originating from the pulmonary veins.

Atrial fibrillation is a cardiac arrhythmia characterised by rapid, and irregular atrial electrical activation, resulting in loss of organized atrial mechanical contraction. These rapid and irregular electrical signals input into the atrioventricular (AV) node, which determines ventricular activation and rate. 

Option A: Increased automaticity in the sinoatrial node can cause sinus tachycardia, in contrast to atrial fibrillation, which primarily occurs due to ectopic foci. 

Option B: Reentry circuits within the atrioventricular node is characteristic of AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), not atrial fibrillation.

Option D: Conduction delay due to bundle branch block: This refers to ventricular conduction abnormalities and is not a primary mechanism for atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
An automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) is a device placed in the chest or abdomen to detect arrhythmias and perform cardioversion, defibrillation, and pace the heart.

It is contraindicated in patients experiencing tachyarrhythmias with reversible or transient causes such as acute MI.

It is used in: 

  • Brugada syndrome- refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death.
  • Ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia.
  • Cardiac resynchronization therapy for prevention of sudden cardiac death in heart failure.
  • High-risk situations of sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Identify the arrhythmia depicted by the given ECG strip:
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts ventricular fibrillation. It has the following characteristics:

  • Chaotic irregular deflections of varying amplitude
  • No identifiable QRS complexes, ST segments, or T waves are visible

Other options:

Option 1- Ventricular tachycardia: The ECG features include:

  • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology
  • Absence of the P waves
  • Rate >100/min

Option 3- Atrial fibrillation: The ECG features include:

  • Narrow QRS complexes
  • RR intervals are irregular
  • No distinct p waves seen

Option 4- Atrial flutter: The ECG features include:

  • Narrow QRS complexes
  • RR intervals are regular 
  • Normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding sick sinus syndrome?

choices.text: Most patients are symptomatic in the early stages
Frequently seen in patients with atrial fibrillation

questions.solution:
Sick sinus syndrome is frequently seen in patients with concomitant atrial fibrillation. 

Sick sinus syndrome (or sinus node dysfunction) is a group of abnormal heart rhythms. It is a disorder of the sinoatrial node caused by impaired pacemaker function and impulse transmission. This leads to a combination of abnormal rhythms, including atrial bradyarrhythmias, atrial tachyarrhythmias, and sometimes a pattern of alternating bradycardia and tachycardia, known as tachy-brady syndrome. These irregular rhythms can cause symptoms such as palpitations, decreased tissue perfusion, subsequent fatigue, lightheadedness, pre-syncope, and syncope. 

The management of sick sinus syndrome includes identifying and correcting reversible factors, as an initial step. 

Some examples of reversible causes of Sinus Node Dysfunction include, 

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Sleep apnea
  • Anti-hypertensive medications eg. Beta-blockers
  • Anti-arrhythmic medications eg. Amiodarone, Procainamide

Ambulatory ECG monitoring is required to diagnose as the symptoms are nonspecific.

Treatment involves permanent pacing. 

Other options:

Option A: The course of sinus node dysfunction is usually a slow progression over decades. In the early stages, most patients are asymptomatic.

Option B: It occurs most commonly in elderly patients due to the gradual loss of SA node function. 

Option D: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in this condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness. Her heart rate is 135 beats/ minute. Her ECG strip is shown below. Which of the following treatment modalities is recommended for definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG finding with delta waves suggest a diagnosis of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). The recommended treatment modality is radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway. 

Wolf Parkinson White (WPW) is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave as seen in the picture.

Patients with WPW may be asymptomatic or have multiple recurrent arrhythmias with chest pain, dizziness, or sudden cardiac arrest. The initial treatment of WPW involves vagal manoeuvres to abort the tachycardia. Pharmacologic therapy with adenosine, verapamil, or beta-blockers can be administered. However, as recurrent arrhythmias may lead to AF, radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway is advised for definitive treatment.

Other options: 

Option A: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is not used to treat WPW. Ablation has a better prognosis. 

Options B and D: Percutaneous coronary intervention and coronary artery bypass grafting are done in patients who have had a myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A cardiologist would make a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation for which of the following patients?

choices.text: A 40 year old hyperthyroid female with atrial fibrillation persisting for about 14 months
A 30 year old male with no cardiovascular ailment having atrial fibrillation since last month
A 45 year old hypertensive male with atrial fibrillation that resolved in 15 days
A 52 year old female with spontaneous atrial fibrillation that resolved in 5 days

questions.solution:
Atrial fibrillation that starts spontaneously and terminates within 7 days is termed paroxysmal AF. As per this definition, the 52-year-old female with spontaneous atrial fibrillation that resolved in 5 days fits into this diagnosis.

Other classifications of atrial fibrillation are

  • Persistent atrial fibrillation - AF that persists for more than 7 days.
  • Longstanding persistant atrial fibrillation  - AF that persists for more than a year.
  • Permanent atrial fibrillation - Longstanding AF that is refractory to cardioversion.
  • Lone atrial fibrillation - AF that occurs in patients younger than 60 years who do not have hypertension or any evidence of structural heart disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old otherwise healthy male presents with paroxysmal episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, and lightheadedness. The episodes typically last for a few minutes and resolve spontaneously. An EKG is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely origin of this EKG finding?

choices.text: Foci of automaticity in the Purkinje system

questions.solution:
Narrow complex tachycardia without visible P waves and sudden onset palpitations as shown in the ECG suggests AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) which is most commonly due to an AV nodal re-entry circuit.

This is the most common type of PSVT, accounting for about 60% of all cases. It occurs when an electrical signal gets trapped in a circuit within the AV node, causing it to fire rapidly and repeatedly, causing a re-entry circuit. This results in a regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia.

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings:

Narrow QRS complex tachycardia at 150 bpm, indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm.
No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) and pseudo-S wave. (II, III, aVF)

Other options:

Option B: Accessory pathway between atrium and ventricle: This can allow electrical signals to bypass the AV node. Wolf Parkinson White is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave.

Option C: Automaticity from multiple atrial foci: Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a type of PSVT caused by multiple atrial foci discharging independently at a rapid rate, this can occur due to lung pathology such as COPD. This results in an irregular narrow QRS complex tachycardia.

Option D: Foci of automaticity in the Purkinje system: Leads to ventricular arrhythmias, which would be charcterized by a wide QRS.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with palpitations for which an ECG is done as shown. She has had multiple such episodes in the past which did not resolve with amiodarone, dofetilide and sotalol. Catheter ablation of which region will terminate this patient’s arrhythmia?

choices.text: Left atrial region around pulmonary vein

questions.solution:
The given ECG indicates Atril Flutter. Ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus can help terminate this patient’s recurrence of atrial flutter that did not resolve with antiarrhythmics.

In patients with recurrences of atrial flutter despite preventive pharmacotherapy such as amiodarone, catheter ablation of cavotricuspid isthmus terminates the arrhythmia. The cavotricuspid isthmus is the atrial myocardium between the tricuspid valve and the inferior vena cava.

The initial management of atrial flutter depends on the patient’s condition and symptoms. If the patient has severe hypotension, angina, or is hemodynamically unstable, then the first step is to perform electrical cardioversion. If the patient’s condition is stable, the initial step is to achieve rate control by administering AV nodal–blocking agents, such as IV beta-blockers.

If the duration of the episode is > 48 hrs, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHADS -VASc scoring system then anticoagulation must be provided before the cardioversion.

For recurrent episodes, antiarrhythmic drugs such as sotalol, dofetilide, disopyramide, and amiodarone may be prescribed. In patients who experience recurrences despite pharmacotherapy, catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus terminates the arrhythmia.

Other Options:

Option B: Catheter ablation of the sinus node is not done for atrial flutter. It is used to treat inappropriate sinus tachycardia.

Option C: Catheter ablation of the region around the pulmonary vein is used to terminate the focus of atrial fibrillation.

Option D: Catheter ablation of the atrioventricular junction is done in cases of chronic atrial fibrillation with inadequate rate control

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents with dizziness, palpitations, and syncope. An ECG reveals the absence of P waves and irregular RR intervals, consistent with atrial fibrillation. Treatment with a class III antiarrhythmic drug is initiated. Which of the following ion channels is most likely targeted by this drug?
questions.solution:
Class III antiarrhythmic drugs, such as sotalol, amiodarone, dofetilide, and ibutilide, are known for targeting voltage-gated potassium channels. These drugs work by prolonging repolarization and the effective refractory period of cardiac cells, which is beneficial in managing tachyarrhythmias like atrial fibrillation.

Other options:

Option A: Voltage-gated nonselective cation channels: These channels are targeted by drugs like ivabradine and affect the pacemaker potential of the sinoatrial node, not the repolarization phase of the action potential.

Option B: Voltage-gated sodium channels: Class I antiarrhythmic drugs target sodium channels, affecting phase 0 depolarization of the action potential, not the repolarization phase.

Option D: Voltage-gated calcium channels: Class IV antiarrhythmic drugs like verapamil and diltiazem target calcium channels, affecting conduction velocity but not directly prolonging repolarization.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male asthmatic patient came to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitation. The patient's vitals were stable and the ECG was performed, which is shown in the image below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) and the drug that can be used for the termination of PSVT in this patient with bronchial asthma is verapamil. 

The mechanism of action of verapamil is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity and it is used in both, acute treatment and prophylaxis of PSVT. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker, which is used in exertional, variant angina, acute coronary syndrome, and heart failure.

Adverse effects include constipation, hypotension, and bradycardia with AV block with concurrent use of beta-blockers. 

Other options:

Option A: Termination of PSVT is done using adenosine, but is avoided in bronchial asthma since adenosine can cause bronchoconstriction.

Option B: Labetalol is a beta-blocker with both alpha and beta-blocking properties used in severe hypertensive crises and generally not used in PSVT.
 
Option C: QRS synchronous direct cardioversion is warranted in cases of PSVT if there is the presence of hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with complaints of palpitations. He is diagnosed with tachyarrhythmia. He is started on a drug that resolves his arrhythmia. ECG taken 3 days after starting medication appears as below, with QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?

 QTc: corrected QT interval
questions.solution:
The patient has a QTc of 477 ms which indicates QT prolongation on taking the drug (normal QT- < 440 ms in males). Among the given options, QT prolongation is seen with procainamide, a Class 1A anti-arrhythmic drug.

A QT interval is slowed by a decreased heart rate. A QTc (corrected QT interval) is calculated as QT/√RR, to remove the effect of HR. Normal QTc is about 440 ms. Values of more than 440 ms in males and 450 ms in females are considered to be prolonged.

A QT prolongation can present as syncope or cardiac arrest. Prompt intravenous administration of 1-2mg magnesium sulfate is needed. It gives time to correct electrolyte imbalances and remove the offending agent.

Other anti-arrhythmic drugs associated with QT prolongation i.e (Class 1A and Class 3):

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG classically depicts polymorphic ventricular tachycardia—torsades de pointes. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

The other cause of torsades de pointes include:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform).
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulphate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate - electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion or intravenous atropine 

Note: Although hypocalcemia is associated with prolongation of QT interval, there are only rare reports of torsades de pointes associated with hypocalcemia. So, among the above options, the best answer would be hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with complaints of syncope and generalized weakness. Her ECG shows a constant PR interval with intermittent non-conducted P waves. Which additional feature on the ECG would indicate a need for immediate pacing?

choices.text: Wide QRS complexes with occasional dropped beats

questions.solution:
The ECG findings are indicative of Mobitz Type II AV block, where there is a constant PR interval and intermittent non-conducted P waves. This type of AV block occurs below the level of the AV node, typically within the His-Purkinje system. The presence of wide QRS complexes with occasional dropped beats is significant because it suggests an infranodal block.

This type of block is more serious as it can rapidly progress to a complete heart block, which can result in severe bradycardia or asystole, leading to hemodynamic instability and potentially life-threatening situations. Immediate pacing is warranted to prevent these complications and ensure the heart maintains an adequate rate to support perfusion.

The primary treatment for Mobitz Type II AV block is the implantation of a permanent pacemaker. This is especially important in symptomatic patients or those with evidence of hemodynamic instability. Temporary pacing may be used as an interim measure until permanent pacing can be arranged

Other options:

Option A: Low voltage QRS complexes are not specific to the severity of Mobitz Type II AV block and do not necessarily indicate a need for urgent intervention.

Option B: Deep T-wave inversions may indicate myocardial ischemia or other conditions, but they do not specifically correlate with the urgency of Mobitz Type II AV block management.

Option C: Prolonged QT interval is associated with an increased risk of torsades de pointes and other ventricular arrhythmias, but it does not directly address the severity or immediate risk associated with Mobitz Type II AV block.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate >100 bpm
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with >3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

MAT is characterised by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia has a rate of 150-200 bpm. It also has a regular rhythm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. It can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation has an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rate is >300 bpm. The 'P' wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter has a regular rhythm. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw-tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: A 32-year-old diabetic man was undergoing a routine check-up. ECG revealed ST changes as given below. Repeated cardiac biomarkers were found to be within the normal range. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows coved ST-segment elevation of V1-V3, followed by a negative T wave (Brugada sign), which points to a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. A coved ST segment has a downward concavity.

Brugada syndrome is an inherited sodium channelopathy (SCN5A mutation) most commonly seen in Southeast Asian males. The age of presentation is usually 40 years. This syndrome is characterised by an increased risk of sudden cardiac death due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

To establish a diagnosis of ST-elevation MI (Option B) and NSTEMI (Option D), a positive and significant rise in cardiac biomarkers (troponins) is necessary along with one of the following features:

  • Symptoms of ischemia
  • New ST-T elevation or LBBB (not for NSTEMI)
  • Pathologic Q waves (STEMI, old infarcts)
  • Imaging evidence of loss of myocardium viability
  • Intracoronary thrombus identified on angioplasty or autopsy

Since we do not have a typical rise and fall pattern of cardiac biomarkers, in this case, a diagnosis of acute ST-elevation MI and NSTEMI is less likely.

Causes of ST-T changes apart from acute MI:

  • Acute pericarditis (Option C) - Diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and PR depression)
  • Brugada patterns (right bundle branch block-like pattern with ST elevations in right precordial leads) seen secondary to electrolyte disturbances like hyperkalemia
  • Hyperkalemia (peaked T waves)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of long QT syndrome presents with recurrent syncope and palpitations. What is the most appropriate long-term management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) insertion is the most appropriate long-term management strategy for this patient. Patients with long QT syndrome (LQTS) who continue to experience recurrent episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) despite optimal medical therapy are at high risk for sudden cardiac death. An ICD continuously monitors the heart's rhythm and can deliver life-saving shocks to terminate life-threatening arrhythmias such as VT.

Other options:

Option A: Beta-blockers are effective in reducing the risk of arrhythmic events in long QT syndrome, particularly in LQT1 and LQT2. However, in high-risk patients who continue to experience arrhythmias despite optimal medical therapy, beta-blockers alone are not sufficient.

Option B: Magnesium sulfate is an effective acute treatment for torsades de pointes, a type of polymorphic VT associated with long QT syndrome. However, it is not suitable for long-term management due to the need for continuous intravenous access and potential side effects. Long-term use is impractical and does not address the underlying risk of sudden cardiac death.

Option D: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug used for various types of arrhythmias. However, it is not the first-line therapy for patients with long QT syndrome due to its potential to further prolong the QT interval and cause proarrhythmic effects. Additionally, ICDs have a proven track record of reducing mortality in high-risk patients, making them the preferred choice over long-term pharmacological therapy.
